Comments_List: How to manage big dataset, interpret them and make plot for better representation and inferring about population statistics.
Learnt how to code on R studio, learnt some basics of statistics.
Stats and a lot of coding in R
The course is well organized, some aspects where thought in a rush which should have gone more into details. But overall is well organized.

Strengths: It's important to learn coding, using R was a nice component. We received our grades very quickly, along with feedback.
Weaknesses: The class was a bit slow, and it would have been better having slides instead of having the professor write down everything on the board.

Lecture organization was poor and expectations were unclear. We might, for instance, spend 3 lectures copying down Dr. Brinda's chalkboard notes and definitions without actually discussing what any of them meant or why they were important. On multiple occasions, a lecture would end with "But you don't need to worry about/know any of this." Deadlines frequently changed. Lectures did not prepare students for quizzes. Gratuitous "hints" about the final quiz and exam content were provided to the class, presumably to get grades back up. While appreciated for the likely positive effects on our GPAs, this decision motivated blunt memorization of material over actually learning and understanding it.
We learned a lot, but the material felt rushed at times, and sometimes I feel like the code wasn't explained thoroughly enough.
If you need to learn how to manage dataset and you have no experience on coding, then it's a great place to start.
Yes, it was a decent class that gave us a lot of R coding practice.
I would not. I was hoping to gain some proficiency in R, which unfortunately was not the case.
